title: Radiation Interactions with Matter
summary: Comprehensive overview of how different types of radiation interact with matter, including photoelectric effect, Compton scattering, pair production, and their clinical implications in radiation therapy.

content.text: Photons interact with matter through three primary mechanisms: photoelectric effect (predominant at low energies), Compton scattering (most important at therapeutic energies), and pair production (significant at high energies >1.02 MeV).

Charged particles like electrons lose energy through coulomb interactions, producing excitation and ionization. The linear energy transfer (LET) and range are important parameters for understanding dose distribution.
Compton scattering is the predominant interaction for megavoltage beams, leading to forward-peaked scatter that affects dose distribution.
